web_research.query: What are winning approaches for text classification with mixed text and tabular features on Kaggle?
web_research.finding: Winning Kaggle solutions for text‑classification tasks that also contain structured (numeric / categorical) columns treat the data as a **multimodal table** and combine a language model with a strong tabular learner.  The most reliable pattern is a two‑stage pipeline: first turn each free‑text column into a dense embedding with a pretrained transformer (e.g., BERT, RoBERTa) or a classic TF‑IDF/word‑n‑gram vector, then concatenate those embeddings with the original numeric and categorical features and feed the whole matrix to a gradient‑boosting model such as LightGBM, CatBoost, or a neural tabular architecture (TabTransformer, FT‑Transformer, TabM).  This approach consistently ranks at the top of the multimodal AutoML benchmark, where “standard two‑stage approaches where NLP is used … then a tabular model is trained on the concatenated features” dominate the leaderboard ([NeurIPS 2021 benchmark](https://datasets-benchmarks-proceedings.neurips.cc/paper/2021/file/9bf31c7ff062936a96d3c8bd

web_research.query: How do Kaggle winners handle class imbalance in binary classification with 25% positive rate?
web_research.finding:
Kaggle winners typically combine a few proven tricks to keep the 75 % / 25 % class split from hurting their models ([Neptune blog on Kaggle binary‑classification tips](https://neptune.ai/blog/tabular-data-binary-classification-tips-and-tricks-from-5-kaggle-competitions)):

1. **Choose an imbalance‑aware metric** – instead of raw accuracy they monitor AUC‑ROC, log‑loss, or F1‑score and decide early whether false‑positives or false‑negatives are more costly ([Kaggle discussion on metrics & weighting](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/questions-and-answers/27589)).

2. **Apply class‑weighting in the loss** – for neural nets they use a weighted binary‑cross‑entropy where the positive class weight ≈ (1‑p)/p ≈ 3 when p = 0.25 ([Weighted BCE notebook](https://www.kaggle.com/code/parthdhameliya77/class-imbalance-weighted-binary-cross-entropy)).

web_research.query: How do Kaggle winners combine text and tabular features for binary classification?
web_research.finding:
Kaggle competition winners typically fuse the raw text column with the remaining numeric / categorical fields by either (a) turning the tabular data into embeddings that are concatenated with a BERT‑style text embedding, or (b) converting the tabular values into a short “feature‑text” string that is prepended to the original document and then fine‑tuned with a transformer. AutoGluon’s multimodal API automates both approaches, letting you train classical tabular models (LightGBM, CatBoost, RF) alongside a pretrained NLP model and blend their predictions ([AutoGluon docs](https://auto.gluon.ai/0.7.0/tutorials/tabular_prediction/tabular-multimodal-text-others.html)) and a simple “features‑to‑text” trick (prepend engineered text to the review before feeding it to BERT) has been shown to give the best single‑model scores on a Kaggle clothing‑review binary label task ([McCormickML blog](https://mccormickml.com/2021/06/29/combining-categorical-numerical-features-with-bert)).

web_research.query: What are the best text preprocessing and feature engineering techniques for Kaggle competitions with Reddit-style posts?
web_research.finding: Text preprocessing for Reddit‑style posts usually starts with a Reddit‑aware tokenizer that can split markdown, URLs, sub‑reddit mentions (r/…), user mentions (u/…), emojis and hashtags while preserving useful tokens. The **RedditScore** library ships a “CrazyTokenizer” with exactly these options and works well as a drop‑in step before any model ([redditScore](https://redditscore.readthedocs.io/en/master)). After tokenization, the typical pipeline mirrors other Kaggle NLP wins: lower‑case everything, strip HTML tags, remove or replace URLs and user mentions, and optionally keep emojis as separate tokens because they often carry sentiment. Stop‑word removal, lemmatization (or light stemming) and the removal of very rare tokens help reduce noise, especially when the dataset is large; many top solutions also truncate or pad to a maximum length to fit transformer‑based models. For very large corpora, memory‑friendly tricks such as loading data with **Dask** or converting to **parquet/feath
